      • _c

        public final int _c()

        The int value. This is so that one can imagine that Int is declared as data Int = 0 | 1 | 2 ... | -maxint | ... | -1

        Specified by:
        _c in interface Value
        Returns:
        0

      • _e

        public final Boxed.Int _e()

        Always this.

        @return this
        Specified by:
        _e in interface Lazy<Boxed.Int>
        Returns:
        the evaluated value or this if it is already evaluated.

      • _v

        public final Boxed.Int _v()

        Always this.

        @return this
        Specified by:
        _v in interface Lazy<Boxed.Int>
        Returns:
        another lazy value that may be a bit closer to the final result.

      • _u

        public final boolean _u()

        Always false.

        @return false
        Specified by:
        _u in interface Lazy<Boxed.Int>
        Returns:
        true, if this is an unevaluated instance of Unknown and false in all other cases.

        This function helps to avoid instanceof and explicit type conversions. It is used by Unknown._e() to decide if another invokation of Unknown._v() is needed.
        Non-lazy values just return false.

      • arrayUpd

        public static final int[] arrayUpd(int[] arr,
             int i,
             int v)

        Update array nondestructively.

        Parameters:
        arr - the array
        i - index into arr
        v - new value to set at index i
        Returns:
        a new array that looks like the old one except that there is value v at index i

      • arraySet

        public static final void arraySet(int[] arr,
            int i,
            int v)

        Update array destructively. This method is not pure!

        Parameters:
        arr - the array
        i - index into arr
        v - new value to set at index i

        Changes the passed array, therefore it is not pure. Because the return type is void there is no way to make the frege compiler believe it is pure.
